prior_works.title: Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference (2nd ed.)
prior_works.role: Foundational framework for structural causal models, do-calculus, and the identifiability problem.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s identification results under functional dependencies are grounded in Pearl’s SCM and do-calculus framework, which defines causal effects, interventions, and the formal notion of identifiability that this work extends.

prior_works.title: Identification of Conditional Interventional Distributions
prior_works.role: Introduced the ID algorithm and hedge obstructions, giving a complete procedure (with later proofs of completeness) for deciding identifiability in semi-Markovian models.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Chen and Darwiche’s key insight—that declaring certain nodes functional can convert previously unidentifiable effects into identifiable ones—operationally interacts with the ID/hedge framework, as their elimination procedure can remove or alter hedges and thereby change ID’s outcome.

prior_works.title: A General Identification Condition for Causal Effects
prior_works.role: Developed graphical decomposition (e.g., c-components) and early algorithmic conditions central to modern identification methods.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s graph-transformation/elimination arguments rely on the same c-component and factorization structures that underlie Tian–Pearl’s conditions, ensuring that identifiability-preserving operations respect these decompositions.

prior_works.title: Markov Properties for Acyclic Directed Mixed Graphs
prior_works.role: Established ADMG semantics and latent projection, the standard way to marginalize variables while preserving implied independences via bidirected edges.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors’ elimination of functional variables leverages latent-projection-style reasoning to remove nodes while preserving key graphical properties relevant to identifiability.

prior_works.title: Equivalence and Synthesis of Causal Models
prior_works.role: Introduced latent projection ideas and Verma constraints, clarifying how marginalizing latent/deterministic structure induces algebraic constraints and mixed graphs.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing how to eliminate functionally determined nodes without losing identifiability-relevant structure, the paper builds on Verma–Pearl’s insights about how marginalization alters graphs and induces constraints.

prior_works.title: Pearl’s Calculus of Intervention Is Complete
prior_works.role: Proved completeness of do-calculus for identification in SCMs.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The completeness of do-calculus underpins the claim that when functional dependencies render effects identifiable, these can in principle be derived via do-calculus after the proposed eliminations.

prior_works.title: Modeling and Reasoning with Bayesian Networks
prior_works.role: Systematized treatment of determinism in graphical models and graph simplifications/variable elimination that preserve key probabilistic properties.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s elimination procedure for functionally determined variables echoes established techniques for exploiting determinism in graphical models to preserve inferential properties while simplifying the graph.

synthesis_narrative: Chen and Darwiche’s central contribution—showing how knowledge of functional dependencies can both unlock identifiability and reduce observational requirements—sits squarely on the modern identification edifice built by Pearl and successors. Pearl’s SCMs and do-calculus formalize causal effects and identifiability, while the ID algorithm of Shpitser and Pearl, together with Tian–Pearl’s c-component factorization, provides the operative machinery and obstructions (e.g., hedges) that define when and why effects are not identifiable. The present work’s key move is a principled elimination of functionally determined variables that preserves identifiability-relevant structure; this relies on latent-projection-style reasoning from Richardson’s ADMG framework and Verma–Pearl’s insights into how marginalization induces bidirected edges and algebraic constraints. By removing functional nodes appropriately, the procedure can disrupt hedge configurations, converting previously unidentifiable targets into identifiable ones under the same do-calculus/ID machinery. Moreover, because deterministic children carry no information beyond their parents, the analysis shows when such variables need not be observed, tightening the observational burden without sacrificing identifiability. The completeness of do-calculus (Huang–Valtorta) guarantees that any new identifications exposed by these eliminations are reachable by standard rules. Finally, the algorithmic flavor and soundness of removing deterministic structure reflect longstanding techniques from probabilistic graphical models (as synthesized by Darwiche) for exploiting determinism while preserving essential inferential properties, here specialized to the causal identification setting.
